questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jerovecii

 

The given scenario is pointing out to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis (aka South American blastomycosis • Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease), presents with oral mucosa lesions, cervical lymphadenopathy, and pulmonary lesions.

 

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, systemic granulomatous disease. On GMS staining, shows tiny oval yeast cells (2–4 µm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

 

Option C. Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, around 60% patients are asymptomatic. Manifests as pneumonia, cavities, pleural effusion or nodule formation, Skin lesions, Arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a critical opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients, characterized by non-specific respiratory symptoms and distinctive cystic structures on Gomori methenamine silver staining. Regular prophylaxis and monitoring are essential for at-risk populations.

choices.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is false and reason is also true
Assertion is true and reason is also false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Myocarditis is the common known complication of faucial diphtheria


Reason (R) : It is due to bacteremia by diphtheria    (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Assertion is true and reason is also false

 

Explanation:

 

Assertion: Myocarditis is indeed a common and serious complication of diphtheria, especially in cases of faucial diphtheria. The diphtheria toxin can cause significant damage to the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis.

 

Reason: The assertion that myocarditis is due to bacteremia by diphtheria is incorrect. Diphtheria does not cause bacteremia. Instead, the complications, including myocarditis, are due to the exotoxin produced by the Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin disseminates through the bloodstream, affecting various organs, including the heart, nerves, and kidneys.

 

  1. Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs.
  2. Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically.
  3. Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason given is not the correct explanation.

 

Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason itself is false.

 

Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true: Incorrect because the assertion is true, but the reason is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myocarditis is a common and serious complication of diphtheria due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin. It is important to recognize that the complications arise from toxemia, not bacteremia.

questions.text: Urine LAM is used for the diagnosis of? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) M. tuberculosis

 

  • Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis.
  • Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen is a lipopolysaccharide present in mycobacterial cell wall.
  • It is released from metabolically active cells or degenerating cells of patients having tuberculosis.
  • Urine LAM testing is especially useful in diagnosing TB in patients with HIV and low CD 4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M. leprae: Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, and its diagnosis is typically made through skin biopsy and slit-skin smear. Urine LAM is not used for diagnosing leprosy.

 

Option C. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma species cause respiratory and urogenital infections. They lack a cell wall and, therefore, LAM is not relevant to their diagnosis.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Listeria monocytogenes is a bacterial pathogen causing listeriosis, diagnosed typically through blood culture or cerebrospinal fluid analysis. Urine LAM is not applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Urine LAM assay is a diagnostic tool for tuberculosis, particularly useful for patients with HIV and low CD4 counts due to the detection of the LAM antigen from mycobacterial cell walls in urine.

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick white vaginal secretions. Which of the following can be used to identify the likely species of the causative agent? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

 

The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of candidiasis. CHROMagar can be used for the rapid identification of Candida species. It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.

 

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1-4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bird seed agar: Mainly used for the isolation and differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans due to its ability to produce brown colonies owing to phenol oxidase activity.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar: A rich, non-selective medium used for cultivating a variety of fastidious organisms, not specific for differentiating Candida species.

 

Option D. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Commonly used for the culture of fungi but does not differentiate between Candida species as effectively as CHROMagar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHROMagar is the preferred medium for rapidly identifying and differentiating various Candida species directly from clinical specimens like vaginal swabs, with Candida albicans typically forming green colonies on this medium. This tool is essential for quick, accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of candidiasis.

choices.text: Antibodies to rabies virus
RT-PCR for rabies virus

questions.text: A patient presents with severe hydrophobia, a classic symptom of rabies infection. Corneal scrapings are collected for diagnostic testing. Which of the following methods is the most reliable and sensitive for confirming the presence of the rabies virus in this sample? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. RT-PCR for rabies virus

 

Explanation:

 

RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing rabies in various clinical specimens, including corneal scrapings. This molecular technique amplifies and detects the genetic material (RNA) of the rabies virus, providing a definitive diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Negri bodies: These are cytoplasmic inclusions found in infected neurons, but their absence does not rule out rabies, and their detection is not as sensitive as RT-PCR.
  • Option B. Antibodies to rabies virus: Antibody detection is less reliable in the early stages of the disease and may not be present in corneal scrapings.
  • Option D. Indirect immunofluorescence: This technique can detect rabies antigens in tissues, but it is less sensitive than RT-PCR and requires specialized expertise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is the gold standard for diagnosing rabies due to its high sensitivity and specificity. It is the preferred method for detecting the rabies virus in various clinical specimens, including corneal scrapings.

questions.text: A person who has undergone a bone marrow transplant in the past is now presenting with a lung lesion. Upon microscopic analysis, the image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable responsible organism for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mucormycosis

 

Explanation:

 

Mucormycosis is indicated in this clinical scenario due to the patient's history of a bone marrow transplant and the presence of a lung lesion. The image provided shows broad aseptate hyphae , which is characteristic of Mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histoplasma: Is a dimorphic fungus. At 25°C, it shows mycelial phase and at 37°C, it shows Yeast form.

 

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: Colonies can be demonstrated by negative staining of their capsule.

 

 

Option D. Aspergillosis: Shows narrow, acute angled branching and septate, differing from the non-septate hyphae

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis  is characterized broad aseptate hyphae with acute -angle branching. which commonly affecting in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Which medication is used to treat an infection caused by the cestode egg of the given organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Praziquantel

 

The egg in the image is of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) and it is treated by praziquantel (5-10 mg/kg once).

 

H. nana egg is colorless, almost transparent, oval, non-bile stained, 30–50 µm (micrometers) in diameter, has polar filaments. When shed in stool they are immediately infective and survive up to 10 days in the external environment, they are embryonated and have a 6-hooked oncospheres inside the shells.

 

Shell consists of two distinct membranes; inner membrane has two small “knobs” or poles from which 4–8 filaments arise and spread.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is used to treat infections caused by various nematodes and ectoparasites but is not effective against cestodes like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option C. Albendazole: Albendazole is an effective treatment for various helminth infections, including some cestodes, but praziquantel is specifically preferred for Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option D. Diethylcarbamazine: Diethylcarbamazine is used primarily for treating filarial infections, not cestode infections like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Educational Objective

 

Praziquantel is the medication used to treat infections caused by the cestode egg of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm). The eggs are colorless, almost transparent, and immediately infective when shed in stool. Praziquantel effectively treats this infection with a single dose of 5-10 mg/kg.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HSV2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) typically presents with painful genital vesicles and can cause painful lymphadenopathy. HSV2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is known for causing recurrent outbreaks of painful vesicular lesions in the genital area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:


HSV2 infection is characterized by painful genital vesicles and can be associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

choices.text: Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide
Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool
It is an obligate intracellular organism

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago comes with complaints of diarrhea for the last 9 days. The stool sample was subject to Kinyoun stain revealing 4-6m structures shown below. Which of the following is true about the organism? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool

 

Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool.

 

Causative organism - Cryptosporidium hominis (more common), C.parvum

 

Causes intractable diarrhoea in immunocompromised patients.

 

Infective form - oocyst.

 

The oocyst is spherical or oval and measures about 5 μm in diameter. Oocyst does not stain with iodine and is acid-fast. The wall of the oocysts is thick, but in 20% cases, wall may be thin. These thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection.

 

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of the oocysts in feces.

 

  • A direct wet mount reveals colorless, spherical oocyst of 4-5 μm, containing large and small granules.
  • The oocysts are difficult to visualize in unstained wet preparations. Modified ZN staining is the method of choice and by this method oocysts appear as red acid-fast spheres, against a blue background.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathogen does not show autoinfection: This is incorrect. Cryptosporidium can indeed cause autoinfection. Thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection, perpetuating the infection within the host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide: While Cryptosporidium parvum is a common cause, Cryptosporidium hominis is more frequently implicated in human infections worldwide.

 

Option D. It is an obligate intracellular organism: Cryptosporidium is not strictly obligate intracellular; it can survive outside the host as an oocyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool, and the infection can cause severe diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts are identifiable by their acid-fast property in modified Ziehl-Neelsen stains.

 

Comparative features of coccidian parasites:

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells
The action of MHC II occurs via endocytic pathway
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens
MHC II is present on antigen presenting cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens

 

MHC Class II molecules are specifically involved in presenting exogenous antigens, ( antigens foreign to the body eg antigens of bacteria, viruses etc)  not endogenous ( self-antigens). These exogenous antigens are typically derived from organisms outside the cell, such as bacteria or viruses that have been ingested by the cell via phagocytosis or endocytosis. MHC Class II then presents peptides from these processed antigens to CD4+ T cells, triggering an immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells: True, which is a key component of the immune response modulation.

 

Option B. The action of MHC II occurs via the endocytic pathway: True, this pathway involves the processing of phagocytosed material.

 

Option D. MHC II is present on antigen-presenting cells: True, which is essential for initiating the immune response by interacting with CD4+ T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction
A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent
FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

questions.text: A patient presents to you with left-sided flank pain. A CT scan was done which is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

 

Above CT image shows left renal hydatid cyst. In this case, FNAC or biopsy should not be done before nephrectomy as puncture of the cyst while obtaining cystic fluid may cause escape of hydatid fluid and consequent anaphylaxis. Therefore, fluid aspirated from surgically removed cyst should only be examined.

 

Echinococcus causes hydatid cyst in man. It is segmented and smaller than other cestodes.

 

Most of the times infection is asymptomatic and accidentally discovered.

 

Clinical disease develops only when the hydatid cyst has grown big enough to cause obstructive symptoms. Disease results mainly from pressure effects caused by the enlarging cysts.

 

In about half the cases, the primary hydatid cyst occurs in liver, mostly in the right lobe. Hepatomegaly, pain and obstructive jaundice are the usual manifestations.

 

The next common site is the lung (25%) (most common being the lower lobe of the right lung). Cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, pneumothorax and dyspnea constitute the clinical picture.

 

In the kidney (2%), hydatid cyst causes pain and hematuria.

 

Apart from pressure effects, another pathogenic mechanism in hydatid disease is hypersensitivity to the echinococcal antigen. The host is sensitized to the antigen by minute amounts of hydatid fluid seeping through the capsule. Hypersensitivity may cause urticaria. But if a hydatid cyst ruptures spontaneously or during surgical interference/FNAC, massive release of hydatid fluid may cause severe, even fatal anaphylaxis.

 

CT imaging is diagnostic to visualize daughter cysts within large cysts

 

Treatment

 

Traditionally surgical removal was considered as the best mode of treatment of cysts.

 

Currently, ultrasound staging is recommended and management depends on the stage.

 

In early stages, the treatment of choice is puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration (PAIR).

 

Puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration, considered as a controversial procedure earlier, is now widely used in early stages of the disease. The basic steps involved in PAlR include:

 

  • Ultrasound or CT-guided puncture of the cyst.
  • Aspiration of cyst fluid.
  • Infusion of sporicidal agent (usually 95% ethanol; alternatively, hypertonic saline)
  • Reaspiration of the fluid after 5 minutes.
  • Great care is taken to avoid spillage and cavities are sterilized with 0.5% silver nitrate or 2.7% sodium chloride for prophylaxis of secondary peritoneal echinococcosis due to inadvertent spillage of fluid du ring PAIR.

 

Albendazole (15 mg/ kg in row divided doses) is initiated 4 days before the procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards.

 

Surgery: It is the treatment of choice for complicated E. granulosus cysts like those communicating with the biliary tract and in those cysts where PAIR is not possible.

 

Renal involvement requires surgical treatment, either simple excision of the cyst or partial/total nephrectomy if extensive disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Albendazole can be started preoperatively: This is correct. Albendazole (15 mg/kg in two divided doses) is initiated 4 days before any surgical or puncture procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards to reduce the risk of spillage and subsequent anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option B. Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction: This is correct. The contents of a hydatid cyst contain highly antigenic material, and rupture or spillage of this material can cause a severe anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option C. A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent: This is correct. Echinococcus granulosus, a segmented tapeworm found in dogs, is the causative agent of hydatid disease.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by cyst formation in organs such as the liver, lungs, and kidneys. FNAC or biopsy should not be done in cases of suspected hydatid cysts due to the risk of anaphylaxis and dissemination of the infection.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA

 

Northern blotting is a laboratory technique used to detect specific RNA sequences within a sample. This method involves the separation of RNA by gel electrophoresis, transfer to a membrane, and hybridization with a labeled complementary DNA probe. The technique allows for the identification and analysis of RNA molecules, making it a valuable tool in gene expression studies and diagnostic applications. The name "Northern blotting" was coined as a play on words, referencing the "Southern blot," a technique used for DNA detection developed by Edward M. Southern.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. DNA: This is detected by Southern blotting, not Northern blotting. Southern blotting involves the identification of specific DNA sequences using DNA probes.

 

Option C. Proteins: This is detected by Western blotting. Western blotting uses antibodies to identify specific protein sequences after separation by SDS-PAGE.

 

Educational Objective

 

SNoW - DRoP:-

 

  1. SOUTHERN - DNA
  2. NORTHERN - RNA
  3. WESTERN - Protein

choices.text: Chancroid is caused by Treponema pallidum and presents with painless ulcers.
Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and presents with painful ulcers.
Chancroid ulcers have hard, indurated edges and do not bleed easily.
Chancroid lesions do not involve regional lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active male presents to the clinic with a genital ulcers that began a week ago. He describes the initial lesion as a small red bump that quickly turned into a sore. On physical examination, multiple superficial ulcers with soft, irregular margins and yellow-gray exudate are noted on the genitalia. The patient also has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. The physician suspects a sexually transmitted infection and considers testing for the responsible pathogen. Which of the following statements about chancroid are true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and presents with painful ulcers.

 

Explanation:

 

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It presents as painful, superficial ulcers with irregular, soft margins and a friable base that often bleeds easily. The ulcers are accompanied by regional lymphadenopathy, which may progress to suppuration if untreated. The characteristic appearance of Haemophilus ducreyi on Gram stain, often described as a "school of fish" or "railroad track" pattern, helps in diagnosis. The condition, also known as "soft chancre," is distinguished by its painful nature and soft ulcer margins, unlike other genital ulcer diseases.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Chancroid is caused by Treponema pallidum and presents with painless ulcers: This statement describes syphilis, not chancroid. Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum and typically presents with painless, hard, indurated ulcers called chancres, which are markedly different from the soft, painful chancroid ulcers.

 

Option C. Chancroid ulcers have hard, indurated edges and do not bleed easily: Chancroid ulcers are characterized by soft, irregular margins that bleed easily when abraded, unlike syphilitic chancres, which have hard, indurated edges and are typically painless.

 

Option D. Chancroid lesions do not involve regional lymphadenopathy: Chancroid frequently involves regional lymphadenopathy, often painful and tender, which can progress to suppurative buboes if left untreated. This is a key clinical feature that helps differentiate it from other ulcerative STIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and presents with painful genital ulcers with soft, irregular margins and associated regional lymphadenopathy. The disease is characterized by its distinct "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain and requires specific growth conditions for culture. Proper identification and differentiation from other sexually transmitted infections are essential for appropriate management.

questions.text: Delayed hypersensitivity is due to? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • Delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) is a form of cell-mediated immune response that occurs typically 24-72 hours after exposure to the antigen. This response is primarily mediated by T-helper 1 (Th1) cells which secrete a variety of cytokines, including Interferon gamma (IFN-γ). IFN-γ is crucial in activating macrophages and enhancing their microbicidal activity, which is a key component of the DTH response. This type of hypersensitivity is important in defense against intracellular pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interleukin-2 (IL-2) - IL-2 is primarily involved in the activation and proliferation of T cells but is not the primary mediator of delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option C. Interleukin-12 (IL-12) - IL-12 plays a role in the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells and can promote IFN-γ production, but it is not the direct mediator of DTH.

 

Option D. Interleukin-4 (IL-4) - IL-4 is associated with the differentiation of naive T cells into Th2 cells and promotes humoral immunity, which is not involved in delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interferon gamma is the key cytokine responsible for mediating delayed hypersensitivity reactions by activating macrophages and enhancing their pathogen-killing capabilities.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

questions.text: Which cell is involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cell

 

Type IV hypersensitivity, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity, involves T cells, particularly cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) and helper T cells (TH1 cells). When these T cells recognize antigen presented by antigen-presenting cells (like macrophages and dendritic cells), they secrete cytokines that activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells. This leads to an inflammatory response that can cause tissue damage. The process typically takes 24-72 hours to develop, hence the term "delayed."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrophage: Macrophages play a crucial role in presenting antigens and secreting cytokines, but they are not the primary cells involved in mediating the type IV hypersensitivity response.

 

Option C. Dendritic cell: Dendritic cells are important antigen-presenting cells that activate T cells, but they are not the main effector cells in type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Option D. Neutrophil: Neutrophils are involved in type III hypersensitivity reactions, where they mediate tissue damage through the release of enzymes and reactive oxygen species in response to immune complex deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which among the following occupation is a risk factor for this presenting illness? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kennel worker

 

The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Parasite eggs are passed in the feces of infected animals (cats, dogs) into the soil, where the larvae hatch out. Hence kennel workers are at high risk.

 

This condition also known as creeping eruption (ground itch) is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

On coming in contact with human skin, the larvae penetrate the skin to cause infection.

 

In normal animal host, the larvae are able to penetrate the deeper layers of the skin by reaching there via circulation.

 

Once they enter intestine, they mature sexually and lay more eggs that are then excreted to repeat the cycle.

 

However, in a human host, which is an accidental host for the parasite, the larvae are unable to penetrate the basement membrane to invade the dermis, so that the disease remains confined to the outer layers of the skin.

 

The larvae produce itching papules, which develop into serpiginous tunnels in the epidermis. With the movements of the larva in the skin, the lesion also shifts, hence the name "creeping eruption''. Scratching may lead to secondary bacterial infection.

 

Transient creeping eruptions may be produced sometimes by the human hookworm, Necator americanus. Gnathostomiasis and sparganosis may produce larva migrans, where the lesions are deeper, subcutaneous or in the muscles. Loeffler's syndrome may occur in one-fourth to one-half of the cases.

 

A rapidly moving lesion is produced by Strongyloides stercoralis particularly in immune persons. This is known as larva currens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lifeguard in a swimming pool: This occupation does not typically involve exposure to soil contaminated with animal feces.

 

Option C. Veterinarian: While veterinarians do work with animals, they are less likely to be exposed to soil contaminated with the specific nematodes causing cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option D. Poultry Worker: This occupation involves working with birds, which are not typically hosts for the nematodes causing this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous larva migrans, caused by nematode larvae from Ancylostoma species, is commonly associated with occupations that involve close contact with contaminated soil and animal feces, such as kennel workers.

 

Additional Information

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On examination of the oral cavity, a white pseudomembrane was visualized. A swab was taken from it and stained as given in the image below. What is the procedure for the following staining? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Albert's stain- I
  2. Acid alcohol
  3. Gram's iodine
  4. Safranin
  5. Methylene blue
  6. Crystal violet
  7. Carbol fuschin
  8. Acetone
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 3, 8, 4

 

The image shows Gram's stain of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae are gram +ve rod shaped bacteria, Club shaped, non-capsulated, non sporing, non-motile,. Also known as Kleb’s-Loeffler Bacillus.

 

The Gram staining process includes four basic steps, including:

 

  1. Applying a primary stain (crystal violet). Option 6
  2. Adding a mordant (Gram’s iodine). Option 3
  3. Rapid decolorization with ethanol, acetone or a mixture of both. Option 8
  4. Counterstaining with safranin. Option 4

 

On microscopy –

 

  • Chinese letter arrangement, V or L shaped
  • Forms granules (metachromatic granules) which are the store house of energy.
  • Alberts’s stain, Loeffler’s methylene blue stain and Ponder’s stain shows metachromatic granules formed in the polar regions. Appears green in Alberts’s stain along with bluish black metachromatic granules at the poles.
    • Albert's I solution - Toluidine blue, Malachite green.
    • Albert's II solution - iodine and potassium iodide.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct Gram staining procedure for identifying Corynebacterium diphtheriae includes the steps of applying crystal violet, adding Gram's iodine, decolorizing with acetone, and counterstaining with safranin.

choices.text: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus
It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria
It promotes the growth of pseudomonas

questions.text: The CLED medium is preferred over other media for the culture of organisms in case of UTI because: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It inhibits proteus swarming

 

Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED) medium is a differential medium used for the isolation and enumeration of bacteria from urine. The medium supports the growth of all urinary potential pathogens and provides distinct colony morphology. It supports the growth of urinary pathogens and contaminants and gives good colonial differentiation without the spread of Proteus species due to its lack of electrolytes.

 

Proteus species are a common cause of UTI and produce swarming on ordinary medias leading to difficult isolation of other important urinary pathogens

 

Bromothymol blue is the indicator used in the agar, it changes to yellow in case of acid production during fermentation of lactose or changes to deep blue in case of alkalinization. Lactose-positive bacteria build yellow colonies. Bacteria which decarboxylate L-cystine cause an alkaline reaction and build deep blue colonies.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus. CLED media does not specifically promote the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus.
 

 

Option C. It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria: This is also true for CLED medium but not the reason why it is specifically used for urinary pathogens. Bromothymol blue is the indicator used in the agar, changing to yellow in case of acid production during lactose fermentation or to deep blue in case of alkalinization. Lactose-positive bacteria form yellow colonies, while bacteria that decarboxylate L-cystine cause an alkaline reaction and form deep blue colonies.

 

Option D. It promotes the growth of Pseudomonas: While Pseudomonas can grow on CLED medium, it is not specifically promoted by this medium compared to the growth of Candida, Streptococcus, and Staphylococcus

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED) medium is a differential medium used for the isolation and enumeration of bacteria from urine. The medium supports the growth of all urinary potential pathogens and provides distinct colony morphology. It supports the growth of urinary pathogens and contaminants and gives good colonial differentiation without the spread of Proteus species due to its lack of electrolytes.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zika Virus

 

The image shows transplacental transmission of Zika virus given causing microcephaly.

 

Zika virus crosses the placental barrier and the developing blood–brain barrier (BBB). ZIKV exhibits clear tropism for proliferative neural cells, often with cytotoxic effects. ZIKV also productively and detrimentally infects cranial neural crest cells (CNCC), which give rise to cranial bones and can exert paracrine effects on the developing brain. Once Zika virions enter neurogenic regions in the brain, they reduce the number of mitotic progenitor cells by promoting cell cycle arrest and apoptotic cell death, autophagy, or possibly by precocious differentiation resulting in microcephaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus primarily causes encephalitis and respiratory illness but does not typically cause congenital infections or microcephaly.

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV can cause congenital infections and microcephaly, but the image and description provided are specific to Zika virus.

 

Option D. Rubella: Rubella virus can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which includes microcephaly among other defects, but the specific viral transmission and pathology detailed in the image refer to Zika virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Zika virus is known for causing microcephaly through transplacental transmission by infecting and damaging neural progenitor cells in the developing fetal brain.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

 

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

 

  • ﻿﻿J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • ﻿﻿Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ig G: Typically exists as a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and extracellular fluid.

 

Option C. Ig M: The largest antibody, mainly in pentameric form, being the first antibody to be produced in response to an infection.

 

Option D. Ig E: Involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections, known for its role in the immune response to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: Which component of the HIV genome is necessary for the virus to enter the host cell membrane? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GP120

 

GP120 is a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope that binds to the CD4 receptors on host cells. This binding is crucial for the initial attachment of the virus to the host cell, facilitating the subsequent steps that lead to viral entry. GP120 interacts specifically with the CD4 receptor, which is predominantly found on the surface of T-helper cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CCR5: CCR5 is a co-receptor on the host cell surface that HIV uses in conjunction with the CD4 receptor to enter the cell. However, it is not a component of the HIV genome but rather a part of the host cell.

 

Option C. GP41: GP41 is another glycoprotein found on the HIV envelope that assists in the fusion of the viral membrane with the host cell membrane after GP120 has bound to the CD4 receptor. It facilitates the entry of the viral core into the host cell cytoplasm.

 

Option D. CXCR4: CXCR4 is another co-receptor used by HIV to enter host cells, particularly in later stages of infection. Like CCR5, it is a part of the host cell and not a component of the viral genome.

 

Educational Objective:


GP120, a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope, is necessary for binding to CD4 receptors on host cells, facilitating viral entry.

choices.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Direct contact with infected animal

 

Direct contact with infected animal is not a known mode of transmission for abdominal TB. Tuberculosis is primarily transmitted via inhalation of airborne droplets from a person with active pulmonary TB. While ingestion of Mycobacterium bovis from unpasteurized milk can lead to abdominal TB, Making it a feco-oral route of spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes: This occurs when TB bacteria spread directly from the mesenteric lymph nodes to the intestines. This form of spread is relatively common in abdominal TB.

 

Option C. Feco-oral route: Ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (from contaminated sputum or unpasteurized milk with M. bovis) can lead to intestinal TB.

 

Option D. Direct contact with infected animal: This is less common but can occur in cases where humans come into contact with animals infected with Mycobacterium bovis, a zoonotic strain of TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modes of spread:

 

  1. By ingesting
    1. Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis
    2. Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis
  2. Hematogenous spread from distant tubercular focus
  3. Contagious spread from infected adjacent foci
  4. Through lymphatic channel
  5. Common site of abdominal TB - Terminal ileum and cecum

 

Feco-oral route is not known to spread abdominal TB.

questions.text:
Korsakoff psychosis is true except? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Amnesia
  2. Confabulation
  3. Ophthalmoplegia
  4. Ataxia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

Korsakoff psychosis is a chronic neurological condition often associated with long-term alcohol abuse leading to vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency. The condition is characterized by severe memory issues, particularly anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) and confabulation (fabrication of memories to fill in gaps in recollection). Patients may also experience retrograde amnesia (loss of pre-existing memories).

 

  • Amnesia: This is a hallmark symptom of Korsakoff psychosis. Patients have significant difficulty forming new memories and may lose some of their older memories.
  • Confabulation: Another key feature, where patients unknowingly create false memories to fill in the gaps of their amnesia. These fabricated memories are often a mix of true events and imagination but are presented by the patient as genuine recollections.

 

Other options:

 

  • Ophthalmoplegia: This condition, characterized by paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles, is not a feature of Korsakoff psychosis but rather of Wernicke's encephalopathy, the acute phase that can precede Korsakoff syndrome if left untreated.
  • Ataxia: Like ophthalmoplegia, ataxia (lack of voluntary coordination of muscle movements) is a symptom of Wernicke's encephalopathy rather than Korsakoff psychosis. Ataxia affects the patient's gait and movement, but it is not present in the chronic Korsakoff stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff psychosis is primarily characterized by amnesia and confabulation, not by ophthalmoplegia or ataxia, which are associated with the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy phase of thiamine deficiency

choices.text: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
Oscillation of water column in the tube

questions.text: Proper functioning of an ICD tube is checked by: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oscillation of water column in the tube

 

Functioning of the ICD tube can be confirmed by seeing the column of water in the chest tube oscillate up and down during respiration.

 

The oscillation or fluctuation of the water column in the water seal chamber of an ICD tube is a key indicator of proper functioning. This movement indicates that there is a patent (open) airway between the pleural space and the water seal, allowing air and fluid to exit the pleural cavity and preventing air from re-entering during inhalation. It's a visual confirmation that the ICD is effectively draining the pleural space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain: While air bubbles can sometimes be seen in the water seal chamber of an ICD system, their presence does not necessarily indicate proper functioning.

 

Option C. Chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable information about the position and placement of the ICD tube, it is not typically used as the primary method for checking its ongoing functioning. X-rays are often performed initially after tube insertion to confirm placement.

 

Option D. Auscultation: Auscultation can help assess lung sounds and detect any abnormalities, but it may not be the most direct method for checking the functioning of an ICD tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

An intercostal drainage (ICD) tube is a thin, plastic tube that's inserted into the pleural space. The pleural space is the area between the chest wall and the lungs. 

 

The ICD tube is used to drain abnormal collections in the pleural cavity. It helps remove: Air (pneumothorax), Blood (hemothorax), Fluid (pleural effusion or hydrothorax, Chyle (chylothorax, Purulence (empyema. 

 

The ICD tube creates negative pressure in the chest cavity, which allows the lung to re-expand.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe dehydration

 

A clinical scenario of a dehydrated child who is drowsy and not able to feed with skin going back very slowly on pinching is suggestive of severe dehydration (as per IMNCI).

 

 

Diarrhea is a condition characterized by a change in the frequency and consistency of stools, occurring more than 3 times a day. Dysentery is a type of diarrhea that is associated with the presence of blood in stools. If the condition subsides within 7 days, it is termed as acute diarrhea, whereas if it persists for more than 2 weeks, it is termed as persistent diarrhea.

 

Acute diarrhea is commonly caused by intestinal infections, with rotavirus and enterotoxigenic E. coli being the major infectious agents. Other causes of acute diarrhea include certain drugs, food allergies, and systemic infections such as urinary tract infection and otitis media.

 

Assessing the degree of dehydration is the most important aspect of evaluating diarrhea. Dehydration can occur due to excessive loss of fluids and electrolytes through diarrhea, which can lead to serious complications. Therefore, it is important to identify and manage dehydration early on to prevent complications

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child with signs of lethargy, poor feeding, and slow skin pinch return should be classified as having severe dehydration and managed urgently as per IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: After the delivery of an infant of a diabetic mother, the blood glucose of the Infant was 60 mg/dl. Which other investigation would you do? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum calcium

 

In infants born to diabetic mothers, it is essential to assess the serum calcium level to rule out hypocalcemia. Infants of diabetic mothers are predisposed to conditions like hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

 

  • Hypocalcemia is defined as a total serum calcium level below 8 mg/dL in term infants and below 7 mg/dL in preterm infants. This condition often occurs due to lower levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in infants of diabetic mothers. In utero, the higher levels of maternal serum ionized calcium may suppress the fetal parathyroid glands, leading to hypocalcemia after birth. If untreated, hypocalcemia can result in neurological symptoms, including seizures, headaches, and neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum potassium: Serum potassium is not directly related to hypoglycemia in infants of diabetic mothers. The primary concern in this scenario is hypocalcemia rather than potassium imbalance.

 

Option B. CBC: While a complete blood count (CBC) can provide useful information, it is not specifically related to the metabolic risks associated with infants of diabetic mothers. Serum calcium is a more appropriate investigation in this context.

 

Option C. Serum chloride: Serum chloride levels do not have a direct connection with hypoglycemia or the other metabolic issues typically seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Therefore, it is not the most relevant test in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In infants of diabetic mothers, it is crucial to monitor serum calcium levels alongside blood glucose to detect and manage hypocalcemia, which can have significant neurological implications if untreated.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a study that is longitudinal, observational, and includes the analysis of variables to determine associations? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

Explanation:

 

  • The correct term for a longitudinal, observational study that involves the analysis of variables to determine associations among a group of people is a "cohort study”.
  • In a cohort study, participants are followed over time to see how different exposures affect their chances of developing an outcome. 
  • It's useful for studying the effects of suspected risk factors that cannot be controlled experimentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-Control Study: This type of study involves identifying participants based on the presence (case) or absence (control) of a particular outcome or disease and then looking back retrospectively to compare exposure to a risk factor or intervention between the groups.

 

Option C. Ecological Study: These studies assess risk factors or outcomes in a population based on data at the group level, rather than individual data. It's useful for initial, broad correlations between environmental or contextual factors and health outcomes.

 

Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): This is an experimental study where participants are randomly assigned to either the group receiving the intervention or to a control group that does not, to compare outcomes in a controlled way.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For analyzing how various factors might affect health outcomes over time within a specified group, a cohort study is typically the most appropriate method due to its ability to follow participants through time and observe changes and outcomes as they occur naturally.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman from Himachal Pradesh presents to the dermatology clinic with a progressively enlarging verrucous skin lesion on her leg. She recalls a thorn prick in the same area about a year ago. The lesion has gradually become wart-like, with rough, raised edges. The patient denies any systemic symptoms. A biopsy of the lesion was performed, and the histopathological findings are shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Phialophora verrucosa

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical history, geographic background, and histopathological findings strongly suggest Chromoblastomycosis, a chronic subcutaneous fungal infection often seen in tropical and subtropical regions. This condition is commonly associated with traumatic inoculation, such as thorn pricks. The histopathological image shows characteristic dark sclerotic bodies, also known as Medlar bodies or copper penny bodies, which are pathognomonic for Chromoblastomycosis. Phialophora verrucosa is one of the common causative agents of this condition, along with other dematiaceous fungi like Fonsecaea pedrosoi and Cladophialophora carrionii.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Sporothrix schenckii is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, which typically presents with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels after a traumatic inoculation such as a thorn prick. However, it is characterized histologically by cigar-shaped yeast forms and does not show the sclerotic bodies typical of Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae: Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, which is characterized by skin lesions, peripheral nerve involvement, and a different histopathological appearance, usually with granulomatous inflammation and the presence of acid-fast bacilli. It does not present with the sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomycosis, caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, is a systemic fungal infection that primarily affects the lungs but can disseminate to the skin. It presents with broad-based budding yeast in tissue samples, not the dark sclerotic bodies associated with Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection caused by traumatic inoculation of dematiaceous fungi, characterized histologically by dark sclerotic bodies known as Medlar bodies. It presents with verrucous skin lesions and requires antifungal therapy or surgical excision for management. Identification of the characteristic histological findings is crucial for accurate diagnosis and differentiation from other subcutaneous infections.

choices.text: Should not be used due to risk of addiction
Can be used as both have different mechanism of action
Should not be used as it is irrational
Can be used to treat cough effectively

questions.text: If Codeine is coming to the market in combination with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive, this combination? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Should not be used as it is irrational

 

  • Codeine is an opioid agonist and Dextromethorphan is a centrally acting NMDA receptor antagonist. Both codeine and dextromethorphan are antitussives, but they work through similar central mechanisms to suppress cough. Combining them does not offer additional therapeutic benefits but can increase the risk of side effects
  • A rational fixed dose drug combination would be to combine one centrally acting anti-tussive (either codeine or dextromethorphan) with expectorants (like potassium iodide, Guaifenesin), antihistaminic and mucolytics like (Ambroxol, Bromhexine, Acetyl cysteine)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Should not be used due to risk of addiction: While codeine has a potential for addiction, the main concern with this combination is not solely the risk of addiction but the lack of rationality in combining two centrally acting antitussives.

 

Option B. Can be used as both have different mechanisms of action: This is incorrect. Codeine and dextromethorphan both act centrally to suppress cough, and their mechanisms are similar enough that combining them does not provide a significant therapeutic advantage.

 

Option D. Can be used to treat cough effectively: Although both drugs are effective cough suppressants individually, their combination is not advisable due to the redundancy in action and increased risk of side effects without additional therapeutic benefit.

 

Therefore, the most accurate answer is C. The combination should not be used as it is irrational due to the overlapping mechanisms of action and increased risk of adverse effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combining codeine with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive is irrational due to their overlapping mechanisms of action and the increased risk of side effects without additional therapeutic benefit. Rational combinations for cough treatment involve combining one centrally acting antitussive with expectorants, antihistamines, and mucolytics.

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraglottic

 

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions.
  • Types of stridor and sites of origin
    • Inspiratory stridor - laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
    • Expiratory stridor - bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
    • Biphasic stridor - laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis and subglottic stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subglottic - More commonly associated with biphasic stridor due to narrowing at the level just below the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Tracheal - Can cause either biphasic or expiratory stridor depending on the extent and exact location of the obstruction.

 

Option D. Bronchus - Primarily causes expiratory stridor due to obstructions in the lower airways.

 

Educational Objective:


Inspiratory stridor is a key clinical sign indicating a potential obstruction in the supraglottic region of the airway. Recognizing this symptom is critical for diagnosing and managing airway obstructions effectively to prevent respiratory distress.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 333, 334

choices.text: Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.
There is no pain on ocular movement.
Multiple myeloma is a common cause.
Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about optic neuritis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.

 

In optic neuritis, a characteristic sign is the presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil. This can be elicited by performing a swinging flashlight test, where a flashlight is moved between the normal and affected eye while observing the pupil response. Normally, both pupils remain constricted when light is shone on them. However, in the presence of RAPD, the pupil in the affected eye will dilate instead of constrict when the light is moved from the normal eye to the affected eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is known as Marcus Gunn pupil, and is an important diagnostic finding in optic neuritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. There is no pain on ocular movement:

 

Pain With Eye Movement

 

  • Pain sensation worsening after movement of the eye ball is specific to typical ON. At the site of the apex, the optic nerve sheath is proximal to the superior and medial rectus. Consequently, when the patient moves the eye ball, contraction of the ocular muscles irritates the inflamed optic nerve sheath to cause the pain . It is less likely for patients with anterior ON to develop pain with eye movement, because the optic nerve sheath of the anterior nerve is not pulled by the ocular muscles.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma is a common cause:

 

  • Isolated ON and MS-associated ON (MS-ON) are usually grouped together as typical ON, since they share concurrent characteristics, including age ranging from 18 to 50, unilaterality, pain with eye movement, rapid vision loss, and the tendency to reach the lowest level of visual acuity within two weeks of onset.

 

(Yang X, Li X, Lai M, Wang J, Tan S, Chan HH. Pain Symptoms in Optic Neuritis. Front Pain Res (Lausanne). 2022 Apr 14;3:865032. doi: 10.3389/fpain.2022.865032. PMID: 35498555; PMCID: PMC9046587)

 

  • Atypical ON, especially the neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) associated ON (NMOSD-ON), is more commonly bilateral (around 20%) than MS-ON
  • For differentiated diagnosis, an oligoclonal band (OCB) is more frequently discovered in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of MS patients (85%) than NMOSD patients (15-30%) . The presence of aquaporin protein 4 antibodies (AQP4-IgG), which are found in more than 90% of NMOSD-ON patients in conjunction with the clinical features, helps to diagnose NMOSD with high sensitivity (99%) and specificity (90%).
  • Due to its unique clinical characteristics, including dominance of male gender, a single attack, better recovery of visual acuity, presentation as ON at onset is usually in adults, but presentation as acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis (ADEM) at onset is mostly in children. MOG associated disorder (MOGAD) is increasingly considered as a disease entity distinct from NMOSD.
  • Clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) refers to that the patient underwent a single or multiple phases of neurologic symptoms that might progressed to MS but at that moment these symptoms cannot fulfill the diagnostic criteria of MS (Karussis, 2014).
  • Multiple myeloma is not a known cause of optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment:

 

  • Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is not recommended for optic neuritis.
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone may be used if radiological evidence of multiple sclerosis is present.
  • Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is associated with an increased risk of new attacks of optic neuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A relative afferent pupillary defect is a critical clinical sign in diagnosing optic neuritis, highlighting the asymmetric impact on optic nerve function. Understanding and correctly identifying this sign is vital for early and accurate diagnosis and management of optic neuritis.

choices.text: Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid

questions.text: The correct pair of lymph node level in the neck and anatomical boundaries amongst the following are? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Level 6 - Hyoid to clavicle

 

Explanation:

 

The correct pair of lymph nodes and levels among the following options are level 6- Hyoid to clavicle.

 

Level 6 lymph nodes are the anterior or central compartment nodes. They span from the hyoid bone (superiorly) to the sternum/clavicle (inferiorly), and from the carotid arteries laterally. This group includes pretracheal, paratracheal, and precricoid (Delphian) nodes. These nodes often come into consideration in thyroid cancers and some laryngeal and hypopharyngeal malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Level 3 - Cricoid to clavicle: This is incorrect. Level 3 lymph nodes are located in the middle jugular region, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the hyoid bone (superiorly) and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (inferiorly). They are situated along the middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

Option B. Level 4 - Hyoid to cricoid: This is also incorrect. Level 4 lymph nodes are the lower jugular nodes, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (superiorly) and the clavicle (inferiorly). These nodes are situated along the inferior third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

Option C. Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid: This is not correct. Level 5 lymph nodes are located in the posterior triangle of the neck, which is bound by the sternocleidomastoid muscle (anteriorly), the trapezius muscle (posteriorly), and the clavicle (inferiorly). Level 5 is further divided into Level 5A (located above the cricoid) and Level 5B (located below the cricoid to the clavicle). So, Level 5 spans from the base of the skull to the clavicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymph node level in the neck and their anatomical boundaries -

 

To aid in the description and localization of lymph nodes, especially in cancer treatment and surgery, they have been categorized into specific levels. Each level is defined by anatomical landmarks.

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

The correct matching of the procedures with their respective characteristics is as follows:

 

  • Amniocentesis (A-4): This procedure involves the assessment of amniotic fluid, often for detecting alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and other genetic conditions. It is generally performed between 15-18 weeks but may be done later as well.
  • Chorionic Villous Sampling (B-1): CVS is performed earlier in pregnancy, typically between 10-13 weeks. It involves sampling of placental tissue to test for chromosomal abnormalities and genetic conditions.
  • Fetal Blood Sampling (C-2): Also known as cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), this procedure is done around 19-20 weeks to obtain fetal blood, often for testing fetal anemia, infections, or genetic conditions.
  • Fetoscopy (D-3): This procedure involves visualizing the fetus directly in utero and is used in specific circumstances to assess fetal anatomy and perform interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1: Incorrect because Chorionic Villous Sampling (CVS) is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetoscopy does not typically involve amniotic fluid assessment.

 

Option B. A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4: Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetal blood sampling is not done at 8-12 weeks.

 

Option D. A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1: Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not used to visualize fetal organs, and Chorionic Villous Sampling is not done at 19-20 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the appropriate timing and purpose of various prenatal diagnostic procedures such as Amniocentesis, Chorionic Villous Sampling, Fetal Blood Sampling, and Fetoscopy.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 882, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 741

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prozone phenomenon

 

The initial negative test is explained by the prozone phenomenon. The standard agglutination test is a tube agglutination test that mainly identifies IgM antibodies. It is used in establishing a diagnosis of acute brucellosis.

 

Prozone phenomenon refers to the failure of a visible precipitation reaction due to inhibition of lattice formation by the presence of excessive antibodies. This gives rise to a false-negative test. This excess in antibodies can be overcome by diluting the serum sample, leading to an increase in LATTICE FORMATION where the antigen-antibody interactions are equal, eventually giving rise to a positive result.

 

Lattice hypothesis: The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. The point where the antigen and the antibody are in the same amount , best interaction takes place in this zone called as the zone of equivalence. 

 

  • Prozone phenomenon: Caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation-false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigens and antibodies are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post-zone phenomenon: Due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incomplete antibodies: These are not typically responsible for the phenomenon described. Incomplete antibodies generally do not cause agglutination but can bind antigens.

 

Option B. Complement inactivation: This would not typically result in the observed test pattern and is more relevant in tests involving complement fixation.

 

Option D. Post-zone phenomenon: Occurs when there is an excess of antigen, not antibodies, leading to a lack of visible agglutination due to insufficient cross-linking by antibodies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The prozone phenomenon, responsible for initial false-negative results in serological tests like the standard agglutination test for brucellosis, occurs due to excessive antibodies preventing visible agglutination. This can be corrected by diluting the serum, which highlights the importance of considering antibody concentration in diagnostic testing.

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms is exclusively dependent on the intracellular environment of a host cell for survival and replication? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Coxiella burnetiid

 

Explanation:

 

Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, is an obligate intracellular bacterium. This means it can only survive and replicate within the cells of a host organism. It has adapted to thrive in the harsh environment of phagolysosomes, the intracellular compartments where cells digest foreign material.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Listeria monocytogenes: This bacterium is a facultative intracellular pathogen, meaning it can survive and replicate both inside and outside host cells.
  • Option C. Klebsiella pneumoniae: This bacterium is an extracellular pathogen, primarily residing and multiplying outside of host cells.
  • Option D. Legionella pneumophila: While Legionella pneumophila is an intracellular pathogen, it is not an obligate one. It can survive and replicate in the environment, but it prefers to invade and replicate within macrophages and other host cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxiella burnetii is unique among the listed organisms as it is an obligate intracellular pathogen, relying entirely on the intracellular environment of a host cell for survival and replication.

choices.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox
She is immune to chicken pox

questions.text: A pregnant woman residing in the same house as her niece, who has contracted Varicella, received a negative result in her test for serum antibodies against varicella. What implications can be drawn from this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) She is susceptible to chicken pox

 

Anti-Varicella/Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)/Chickenpox IgG; Varicella immunity test

 

  • Negative: Indicates no detectable Varicella IgG antibodies. A negative results indicate no current or previous infection with Varicella virus. Such individuals are presumed to be susceptible to primary infection.
  • Equivocal: Equivocal results are indeterminate. Patient may or may not have immunity to Varicella Virus. It is not acceptable proof of immunity.
  • Positive: Indicates evidence of Varicella IgG antibodies and suggests past or current infection with Varicella virus. Antibodies obtained via acquired immunity or immunization and probable protection from clinical infection. (Immunity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. She is immune to zoster: Incorrect. Immunity to zoster (shingles) comes from having had a previous varicella (chicken pox) infection or vaccination. A negative antibody test indicates she has not had varicella.

 

Option B. She is susceptible to zoster: Incorrect. Susceptibility to zoster (shingles) typically arises from a reactivation of the varicella virus in individuals who have previously had chicken pox. A negative test means she has not had chicken pox, so she cannot develop zoster but is susceptible to chicken pox.

 

Option D. She is immune to chicken pox: Incorrect. A negative antibody test indicates she does not have immunity to chicken pox.
 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative test result for serum antibodies against varicella indicates that the individual is susceptible to chicken pox, as there are no detectable antibodies suggesting past infection or vaccination.

questions.text: If DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, which gene causes cell cycle arrest? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) p53

 

  • Tumor suppressor gene causes cell cycle arrest (to provide time for DNA repair) and apoptosis (if DNA cannot be repaired). Acts mainly through p21 to cause cell cycle arrest. Causes apoptosis by inducing the transcription of pro-apoptotic genes such as BAX. Levels of p53 are negatively regulated by MDM2 through a feedback loop.
  • p53 is required for the G1/S checkpoint and is a main component of the G2/M checkpoint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rb: The Rb (retinoblastoma) protein is another tumor suppressor that plays a role in regulating the cell cycle. Rb controls the progression from the G1 to S phase by binding to and inhibiting E2F transcription factors. While Rb is critical for cell cycle regulation, it does not directly mediate the response to DNA damage like p53.

 

Option B. MYC: The MYC gene is a proto-oncogene that promotes cell proliferation by driving the expression of genes necessary for cell growth and division. It does not cause cell cycle arrest in response to DNA damage; instead, its dysregulation is often associated with uncontrolled cell proliferation.

 

Option D. K-RAS: K-RAS is a proto-oncogene involved in cell signaling pathways that regulate cell growth and survival. Mutations in K-RAS can lead to uncontrolled cell division and are implicated in many cancers. However, K-RAS does not have a direct role in DNA damage response or cell cycle arrest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The p53 gene is a critical tumor suppressor that causes cell cycle arrest in response to DNA damage, providing time for DNA repair or triggering apoptosis if the damage is irreparable.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, pg 527

choices.text: 1, 2 and 3
1, 2 and 4
1, 3 and 4
2 and 4 only

questions.text:
The anti-epileptic drugs which can also be used for the treatment of neuropathic pain are: (INICET Nov 2021)

 

1. Pregabalin

2. Carbamazepine

3. Lamotrigine

4. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2 and 4

 

The question relates to the use of certain anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) for the treatment of neuropathic pain.

 

  1. Pregabalin: This is an AED that's also commonly used for neuropathic pain. It works by binding to calcium channels in the central nervous system and reducing the release of neurotransmitters. It is used in the management of neuropathic pain associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy, spinal cord injury or postherpetic neuralgia.

 

  1. Carbamazepine: Initially used as an anti-seizure medication, carbamazepine is also effective for certain types of neuropathic pain, particularly trigeminal neuralgia.

 

4. Gabapentin: Similar to pregabalin, gabapentin is used both as an AED and for the treatment of neuropathic pain. It also affects calcium channels and reduces neurotransmitter release. It is mainly used in the management of neuropathic pain due to postherpetic neuralgia in adults.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Lamotrigine: While lamotrigine is an AED, its use in neuropathic pain is less established compared to pregabalin and carbamazepine. It may have some efficacy, but it's not a first-line treatment for neuropathic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pregabalin, carbamazepine, and gabapentin are anti-epileptic drugs that are also effective in treating neuropathic pain. These medications are utilized not only for seizure control but also for managing various forms of chronic pain associated with nerve damage.

choices.text: Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g

questions.text: To accurately calculate the perinatal mortality rate, which of the following should specifically be considered as part of the numerator? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g 

 

Perinatal Mortality Rate (PNMR)

 

  • It includes both late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.

 

 

  • Perinatal period is from 28 weeks period of gestation to 7th completed days of life (But the WHO definition of perinatal period is from 22 completed weeks gestation to 7th completed days of life).
  • PNMR is a major marker to assess the quality of health care delivery; PNMR is a” Yardstick of Obstetric and Pediatric care before and around the time of birth”
  • P List (ICD 10): 100 causes of perinatal mortality and morbidity
  • PNMR of India (2022) - 18 per 1000 LB (SRS, September 2022)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perinatal mortality rate includes late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths, focusing on the period from 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student developed epistaxis that resolved spontaneously. He has been afebrile for the last 24 hours and his platelet count is 14,000/µL. His BP is 110/70 mm of Hg and there is a 28% rise in hematocrit. What should be the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Give 4 units of platelets

2. Give plenty of oral fluids

3. Give IV fluids

4. Keep under observation

5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3 and 4

 

The patient likely has Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever, indicated by a significant rise in hematocrit, which suggests plasma leakage during the critical phase of the illness. The management strategy includes:

 

  • Statement 2. Oral fluids to maintain hydration but must be balanced to avoid fluid overload.
  • Statement 3. IV fluids are essential for the management of severe dengue to correct the plasma leakage and prevent shock.
  • Statement 4. Observation is crucial to monitor for further complications such as dengue shock syndrome.
