Option A. 1 and 2: Platelet transfusion is generally reserved for severe bleeding or very low platelet counts (typically <10,000/µL without bleeding). This patient's platelet count, while low, does not alone justify transfusion without signs of active or severe bleeding.

 

Option C. 1, 2 and 4: Includes unnecessary platelet transfusion without the clear presence of severe bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Option D. 2 and 5: Discharging the patient is inappropriate given the potential for rapid deterioration during the critical phase of dengue fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In dengue hemorrhagic fever, management focuses on careful fluid management and close observation during the critical phase to prevent or manage complications such as shock. Platelet transfusions are not routinely given based solely on low counts but are reserved for cases of significant clinical bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Note - There is no correlation between bleeding manifestation and platelet count.

 

Reference - Dengue Case management for Clinicians- CDC

choices.text: Conversion of uric acid to allantoin

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with chronic gout is under consideration for a change in treatment plan due to poor response to conventional therapies like allopurinol and colchicine. The healthcare team is discussing the potential use of pegloticase. What is the mechanism of action of pegloticase?" (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of uric acid to allantoin.

 

Pegloticase is a recombinant uricase enzyme that converts uric acid into allantoin, which is more soluble and easier to excrete through the kidneys. This action helps to lower high levels of uric acid in patients with chronic gout who have not responded well to conventional therapies such as allopurinol and colchicine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of xanthine oxidase: This is the mechanism of action for allopurinol, not pegloticase. Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, which is an enzyme involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid.

 

Option C. Increase excretion of uric acid: Some medications like probenecid work by this mechanism to increase the renal excretion of uric acid.

 

Option D. Inhibition of granulocyte migration: Colchicine works through inhibiting granulocyte migration, but pegloticase primarily works by metabolizing uric acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegloticase works by converting uric acid to allantoin, a more soluble compound that is easily excreted by the kidneys. This mechanism is distinct from other gout treatments and is particularly useful for patients with refractory chronic gout.

questions.text: What is the root value of cremasteric reflex? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. L1, L2

 

Explanation:

 

The cremasteric reflex is mediated through the sensory fibers of the ilioinguinal nerve (L1) and the motor fibers of the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2). When the inner thigh is stroked, sensory impulses travel via the ilioinguinal nerve to the spinal cord segments L1 and L2, and motor impulses from these segments, through the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, cause the cremaster muscle to contract, pulling the testicles upward.

 

The cremasteric reflex's afferent and efferent branches:

 

  • Afferent - Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Efferent - Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8, T9: These thoracic spinal nerve roots primarily innervate the muscles and skin of the thoracic region and contribute to the intercostal nerves. They are not involved in the cremasteric reflex.

 

Option C. L3, L4: These lumbar spinal nerve roots are primarily associated with the front of the thigh and the medial side of the leg and foot. The femoral nerve, which is the largest nerve arising from the lumbar plexus, is derived from these roots. These roots are not directly involved in the cremasteric reflex but are important for the patellar (knee-jerk) reflex.

 

Option D. S1, S2: These sacral spinal nerve roots play a major role in innervating the posterior thigh, most of the leg and foot, and the perineum. They contribute to the sciatic nerve, among others. Reflexes like the ankle jerk (Achilles reflex) involve these nerve roots. They are not associated with the cremasteric reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cremasteric reflex is mediated by L1 and L2. In this reflex, there is ipsilateral elevation of the testicle following stroking of the medial thigh.

 

Other clinical reflexes and their root values: -

 

Achilles reflex – S1, S2

Patellar reflex – L3, L4

Biceps and brachio-radialis reflexes – C5, C6

Triceps reflex – C7, C8

Anal wink reflex – S3, S4

Abdominal reflex – T7 – T12

choices.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, direct Coombs test

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought with pallor and jaundice. On examination he had a hemoglobin of 9g/dl and mild splenomegaly. He has a history of similar episodes from birth.  The peripheral smear had red cells without central pallor. Which of the following is useful for making the diagnosis of the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility test 

 

Presence of mild jaundice, splenomegaly and anemia is suggestive of hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis. Since the history of similar episodes since child birth is present it is more likely a familiar case and so, the most appropriate answer is hereditary spherocytosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, direct Coombs test: While autoimmune hemolytic anemia also presents with hemolysis, the history of episodes from birth and the specific peripheral smear findings are more suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Typically presents with acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, not with a chronic history from birth.

 

Option D. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): Characterized by intravascular hemolysis, hemoglobinuria, and a different set of laboratory findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis should be suspected in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and spherocytes on a peripheral smear. The osmotic fragility test is a key diagnostic tool for this condition.

 

  • Spherocytes are more fragile in hypotonic solutions due to reduced surface area-to-volume ratio.
  • Newer and more sensitive tests include EMA (Eosin-5-maleimide) binding test by flow cytometry.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling and difficulty in swallowing food. Histopathological examination of the swelling shows increased nests of cells with amyloid deposition. Which of the following is the cell of origin of this mass?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parafollicular cells

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is the type of thyroid cancer associated with increased nests of cells and amyloid deposition. MTC arises from the parafollicular cells (also known as C cells) of the thyroid. These cells produce calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The presence of amyloid in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin, which can be detected as amyloid material in histopathological examinations. This type of thyroid cancer is distinct from other forms such as papillary, follicular, or anaplastic thyroid carcinomas, which originate from follicular cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial cells: Incorrect. Endothelial cells line blood vessels and are not associated with thyroid tumors that show amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular cells: Incorrect. Follicular cells give rise to papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid cancers, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Hurthle cells: Incorrect. Hurthle cells are a variant of follicular cells and can be seen in Hurthle cell carcinoma, another type of thyroid cancer, but not in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma, characterized by nests of cells and amyloid deposition, arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

 

Explanation:

 

  • Misoprostol and Mifepristone:
    • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
    • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
    • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
    • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.

 

Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.

 

 

Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules

choices.text: Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water
It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines
Photograph is taken with two scales at right angle to one another in the vertical plane
3D imaging is possible in the given condition

questions.text: A mentally challenged person bites his brother on the hand during a physical fight. All of the following statements are true about the given condition except? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Photograph is taken with two scales at right angle to one another in the vertical plane

 

The correct method for photographing bite marks is to use two scales placed at right angles to each other in the horizontal plane. This positioning ensures that the dimensions and orientation of the bite mark are accurately recorded for forensic analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water: Correct. Swabbing the bite mark is essential for collecting DNA evidence, which can be critical in identifying the biter.

 

Option B. It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines: Correct. Bite marks are typically made by the front teeth, especially the incisors and canines, which are used to grasp and tear.

 

Option D. 3D imaging is possible in the given condition: Correct. 3D imaging can be used to analyze bite marks more accurately, providing detailed information about the depth and pattern of the bite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a human bite mark:

 

  • Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water
  • It is most commonly caused by front teeth - incisors and canines
  • Photograph is taken with two scales at right angle to one another in the HORIZONTAL plane
  • 3D imaging is a valuable tool for analysis

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, diplopia, hoarseness, dysphagia and left Horner's syndrome associated with numbness of the left face and right-side limbs. Which artery is affected in this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Clinical features are suggestive of Lateral Medullary syndrome/Wallenburg syndrome which occurs due to PICA occlusion. His syndrome is characterized by a range of neurological deficits due to ischemia in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata, where PICA provides blood supply.

 

Clinical Features Associated with PICA Occlusion:

 

  • Vertigo and Diplopia: Caused by the involvement of the vestibular nuclei and adjacent structures.
  • Hoarseness and Dysphagia: Result from damage to the nucleus ambiguous, affecting the vagal and glossopharyngeal nerve functions.
  • Horner’s Syndrome: Occurs due to disruption of the sympathetic pathways.
  • Numbness of the Face and Contralateral Limbs: Caused by damage to the spinal trigeminal nucleus and the spinothalamic tract, respectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA): Affects a similar region but typically presents with symptoms like hearing loss due to its supply to the inner ear structures, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option C. Superior Cerebellar Artery: Occlusion typically results in ataxia and coordination difficulties without the cross-sensory loss observed in Wallenberg's Syndrome.

 

Option D. Basilar Artery: A much broader array of symptoms would be expected, potentially affecting multiple cranial nerve and long tract functions simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Image: Arteries involved in brainstem syndromes lateral vs medial brainstem

 

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Chap 426, Neurology/stroke

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with a painful lump in her breast that has been increasing in size over the past few days. After examination, the doctor diagnoses her with a breast abscess and prescribes antibiotics to help clear the infection. The doctor attempts to aspirate the abscess using a needle and syringe, but no fluid is obtained. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A second attempt at aspiration

 

Explanation:

 

If the first attempt at aspiration fails to obtain fluid, the next logical step is to attempt aspiration again, potentially with ultrasound guidance. Ultrasound guidance can enhance the accuracy of the procedure by allowing direct visualization of the abscess, ensuring that the needle is correctly positioned to access the abscess cavity. This method is less invasive than incision and drainage (I&D), making it a preferred option if it can effectively manage the abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and Drainage: Incision and drainage is generally considered if aspiration fails repeatedly or if the abscess is too large. While effective, it is not typically the immediate next step after a single failed aspiration attempt. It is more invasive than aspiration and usually reserved for cases where less invasive methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option B. Continue antibiotics only: Antibiotics are crucial in managing breast abscesses by treating the underlying infection. However, they alone might not suffice for large or dense abscesses. The pus trapped within the abscess often needs to be physically removed to expedite healing and provide symptom relief. Continuing antibiotics without addressing the abscess can lead to prolonged infection and discomfort.

 

Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected: This option is not recommended. The failure to collect aspirate does not imply the absence of infection. The antibiotics were prescribed based on the clinical diagnosis of a breast abscess, and stopping them prematurely could allow the infection to worsen. Continuation of antibiotics is important until the course is complete or unless indicated otherwise by a physician.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the initial aspiration attempt for a breast abscess fails, the next step should be to attempt aspiration again, preferably under ultrasound guidance, before considering more invasive procedures like incision and drainage. This approach ensures accurate access to the abscess and minimizes invasiveness.

questions.text: The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. Identify the site of action of beta-lactam antibiotics. (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Beta lactams act on step 4 in the given image.

 

The beta lactams inhibit the formation of bacterial cell wall by inhibiting the Transpeptidase enzyme which is required for the cross linking of the peptidoglycan chains; therefore, they lead to a reduction in the strength of the bacterial cell wall which ultimately causes it to burst, leading to the death of the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

 

Option B. 2: Bacitracin inhibits step 2 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation of the BP transporter which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall.

 

Option C. 3: Vancomycin inhibits step 3 in the image. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-lactam antibiotics act at step 4 in the bacterial cell wall synthesis process by inhibiting transpeptidase enzymes, which are essential for cross-linking peptidoglycan chains, thereby weakening the bacterial cell wall and causing cell lysis.

questions.text: Which of the following enhances iron absorption? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Option B: Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) – Correct Answer

  • Enhances iron absorption by:
    • Reducing ferric iron (Fe³⁺) to ferrous iron (Fe²⁺) — the absorbable form.
    • Forms soluble complexes with iron in the gut, preventing precipitation.
       

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vitamin A: While important for overall health, it does not directly enhance iron absorption.

 

Option C. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Essential for carbohydrate metabolism, but it does not affect iron absorption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Important for various metabolic processes but does not directly enhance iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin C enhances iron absorption by reducing ferric ions (Fe+++) to ferrous ions (Fe++) and forming a chelate that protects iron from oxidation, thereby facilitating its absorption in the intestine.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is known to produce urease, aiding in its survival in acidic environments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Helicobacter pylori

 

Explanation:

 

Helicobacter pylori is a well-known urease-producing bacterium that survives in the acidic environment of the stomach. Urease hydrolyzes urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide, which neutralizes gastric acid, creating a protective niche for H. pylori. This enzymatic action is critical for the bacterium's colonization and contributes to its pathogenicity, leading to conditions such as peptic ulcers and chronic gastritis. The detection of urease activity, such as with a urease breath test, is commonly used to diagnose H. pylori infection.

 

Other Options

 

Option A) Escherichia coli: E. coli does not produce urease. Although it is commonly associated with gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections, it lacks the urease enzyme and does not utilize urea hydrolysis for survival or pathogenicity.

 

Option C) Streptococcus pneumoniae: This organism is a common cause of respiratory infections such as pneumonia, but it does not produce urease. Its pathogenic mechanisms involve capsule formation, pneumolysin production, and adherence factors, not urease activity.

 

Option D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Pseudomonas is a versatile bacterium known for its resistance to antibiotics and biofilm formation, but it does not produce urease. Its pathogenicity is primarily driven by toxins and other virulence factors unrelated to urease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Helicobacter pylori produces urease, an enzyme that helps it survive in the acidic environment of the stomach by converting urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide, thus neutralizing stomach acid. This enzymatic activity is pivotal for its pathogenicity in conditions such as peptic ulcers and chronic gastritis.

 

Urease-producing organisms: (Mnemonic-PUNCH)

 

  • Proteus
  • Ureoplasma urealyticum
  • Nocardia
  • Cryptococcus, Corynebacterium urealyticum
  •  H. pylori

choices.text: Treatment of migraine
Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome
Prophylaxis of ADHD
Treatment of dementia

questions.text: Topiramate is used for? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome

 

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that can be used for the treatment of Lennaux-Gestaut Syndrome (characterized by multifocal seizures, having <2.5 Hz spike and wave pattern in EEG). It primarily works by blocking the Na+ channels, and to some extent it also enhances the GABA receptor currents and limiting the activation of the AMPA-kainate subtype of glutamate receptors.

 

Topiramate can also be used for:

 

  • C: Decreasing the Craving of alcohol
  • O: Obesity
  • M: Migraine Prophylaxis (not treatment)
  • B: Bipolar disorder.

 

So, among the given options, best answer is Lennox Gastaut syndrome. Do not get confused with migraine as the options specifically mentions the treatment of migraine whereas topiramate is used for prophylaxis of migraine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment of migraine: Topiramate is used for the prophylaxis of migraines, not for the acute treatment of migraine attacks.

 

Option C. Prophylaxis of ADHD: Topiramate is not indicated for the prophylaxis or treatment of ADHD.

 

Option D. Treatment of dementia: Topiramate is not used for the treatment of dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topiramate is primarily used for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy in children. It is also used for the prophylaxis of migraines, reducing alcohol cravings, aiding in weight loss, and as an adjunct therapy for bipolar disorder.

choices.text: Blood smear for malaria parasites
Tuberculin skin test (Mantoux test)
rK39 antigen test for Leishmaniasis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of frequent international travel, particularly to rural areas in South Asia and Africa, presents with prolonged fever, weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. A bone marrow aspirate is performed, and the findings are shown in the image below. Which investigation would be the most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. rK39 antigen test for Leishmaniasis

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows macrophages infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies, characterized by the presence of kinetoplasts and a characteristic double dot appearance (Leishman stain), suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (VL). Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites transmitted through the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies. The rK39 antigen test is a rapid and highly specific immunochromatographic test that detects anti-k39 antibodies, which are secreted in various body fluids, including blood, and is widely used for diagnosing VL. The test offers a quick, sensitive, and specific diagnosis, making it the investigation of choice for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Blood smear for malaria parasites: Although malaria is a common cause of fever in travelers, the bone marrow findings and clinical presentation are not consistent with malaria. Malaria typically shows ring forms, trophozoites, and schizonts in peripheral blood smears rather than intracellular bodies as seen in leishmaniasis.

 

Option B. Tuberculin skin test (Mantoux test): This test is used for diagnosing latent tuberculosis infection but is not relevant in this case. Tuberculosis does not present with intracellular protozoa in bone marrow aspirates and is not transmitted by sandflies.

 

Option D. HIV serology: Although HIV can cause prolonged fever and weight loss, the bone marrow findings do not suggest HIV-related changes. HIV is not diagnosed through the identification of Leishmania parasites in the bone marrow, and the clinical scenario strongly points toward visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis should be considered in patients with fever of unknown origin, hepatosplenomegaly, and travel history to endemic areas. The rK39 antigen test is a rapid and specific diagnostic tool for visceral leishmaniasis, detecting antibodies against the parasite’s antigens. Bone marrow or splenic aspirate showing intracellular Leishmania bodies remains the gold standard for confirmation.

questions.text: What will the corrected reticulocyte count if Hb is 5 g/dl and absolute reticulocyte count is 9%? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 

 

Calculation:

 

Average Hb value to be taken as 15 g/dl.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corrected reticulocyte count is essential in evaluating the bone marrow response in anemic patients. It is calculated by adjusting the absolute reticulocyte count according to the degree of anemia (using actual and normal hemoglobin values).

questions.text: A patient is planned to undergo hysteroscopic polypectomy using bipolar electrocautery. What is the ideal agent for distention? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal saline

 

 Explanation:

 

  • In bipolar cautery, electricity has to be conducted from one electrode to the other. So normal saline is preferably used.
  • If a monopolar resectoscope is used, then a non-electrolyte solution like glycine is required.

 

Fluid media in Hysteroscopy:

 

The following distension media can be used in hysteroscopy

 

  • CO2: Good for diagnostic procedures but not for operative hysteroscopy
  • Normal Saline
    • Not to be used with monopolar electrocoagulation
    • Good for minor procedures using bipolar instruments/ office procedures as there is very less risk of electrolyte imbalance
  • Dextran 70
    • Useful in patients with bleeding as it does not mix with blood
    • Can cause anaphylaxis, electrolyte imbalance ans fluid overload
  • Low viscosity, nonconductive fluids like: 1.5% Glycine, 3% sorbitol and 5% mannitol
    • Used in operative hysteroscopy using monopolar resectoscopes
    • Safe as there is no electrolytes to disperse the current and impede the electrosurgical effect
    • Associated with electrolyte disturbances and fluid overload

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal saline is the ideal distention medium for hysteroscopic procedures using bipolar electrocautery due to its suitability in conducting electricity between electrodes without causing significant electrolyte imbalance.

 

Ref: Page no 793, Novaks Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemagglutination Test

 

The Hemagglutination Test does not involve antibody marking. This test is used primarily to detect the agglutination of red blood cells (RBCs) by substances such as viruses or anti-blood group antibodies. The principle behind hemagglutination involves the ability of certain entities like viruses to bind directly to receptors on the surfaces of RBCs, causing them to clump together without the need for an antibody to be present as a marker.

 

It is routinely performed to type red blood cells in ABO blood-typing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses antibodies that are tagged with an enzyme to detect the presence of antigens or other antibodies in a sample through a colorimetric change.

 

Option B. Radioimmunoassay: Involves antibodies or antigens labeled with a radioactive isotope to measure the concentration of substances in the blood.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Utilizes antibodies labeled with fluorescent dyes to detect specific antigens in tissues or cells under a fluorescence microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hemagglutination test is unique in its use of direct interactions between particles (like viruses) and red blood cells to demonstrate binding and agglutination, distinguishing it from other tests that rely on labeled antibodies to indicate the presence of specific antigens or antibodies. This method is particularly useful in blood typing and viral detection.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses exhibits genetic re-assortment similar to that of influenza virus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Rotavirus exhibit genetic reassortment similar to that of influenza virus.

 

Rotaviruses - Cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. Genome consists of double-stranded RNA with 11 segments. Segmented RNA helps in easy reassortment of the genome.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Adenovirus can be identified by their icosahedral symmetry with and fibers extruding from the vertices. It is a double stranded DNA virus.

 

 

Option C. Ebola viruses are cylindrical/tubular, and contain viral envelope, matrix, and nucleocapsid components. The virus generally appears in a long, filamentous form, but it can also be “U-shaped,” in the shape of a “6” (the “shepherd’s crook” appearance), or even circular. It is non-segmented and contains single stranded RNA.

 

 

Option D. Rabies viruses belong to Rhabdoviridae which are bullet-shaped viruses with unsegmented single-stranded RNA

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Rotaviruses have a segmented RNA genome that allows them to undergo genetic reassortment similar to influenza viruses.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:

 

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate for treating HSV, inducing labor is not recommended due to the high risk of neonatal infection with vaginal delivery in the presence of active primary HSV lesions.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Spontaneous vaginal delivery poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can lead to severe complications and high mortality. This is not recommended in the case of primary genital HSV.

 

Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Antiviral treatment is necessary, but normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of primary genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term, the best treatment option is to start antiviral therapy and plan for an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes infection.

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Transcervical resection of septum

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcervical resection of septum

 

Explanation:

 

  • Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.
  • The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of Cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the obstetric outcomes.

 

 

Other Options

 

Metroplasty is a type of unification procedures in mullerian anomalies

 

Option A. Jones metroplasty and Option C. Tompkins metroplasty are for septate uterus but are not preferred now. As now the treatment of choice is hysteroscopic resection of the septa.

 

Option B. Strassman metroplasty: Strassman metroplasty is for bicornuate uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the best corrective procedure for a septate uterus to improve obstetric outcomes, as it does not scar the uterus and allows for future vaginal deliveries.

 

Ref: Page no 659, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition
